_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: T-1003A shell and roof external ultrasonic and visual inspections by API-653 Authorized Inspector, T-1003A level transmitters, alarms and interlocks
_prev_prog_3.Description: Nebraska Energy LLC has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by Nebraska Energy LLC efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of Nebraska Energy LLC processes.  Nebraska Energy LLC policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, Nebraska Energy LLC trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the faicility and / or notify the necessary outside agencies.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Nebraska Energy LLC, located in Aurora, Nebraska, U.S.A., operates processes to produce ethyl alcohol which is denatured with natural gasoline.  The natural gasoline used by Nebraska Energy LLC to denature alcohol contains the following flammable regulated substances:

Isopentane                Pentane

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS

The worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a release of flammable substance(s) at Nebraska Energy LLC is a vapor cloud explosion (VCE) involving 229,529 pounds of a flammable mixture contained in a single storage tank.  The entire inventory is assumed to release and ignite, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  Since this facility is located in a low population area, the WCS could not affect nearby residential public receptors, but may affect adjacent commercial or industrial public receptors.  The maximum distance to the 1-psi endpoint for this WCS is 0.2 miles.  Credit for passive mitigation measures was taken for the dike surrounding the single storage tank during the evaluation of this WCS.

The alternative release scenario (ARS) for flammable substances at Nebraska Energy LLC is a liquid pool fire resulting from the release of a flammable mixture from over filling the single storage tank (43,576 pounds released in 26 minutes). The release is expected to be isolated by plant operations personnel within 10 minutes. Since this facility is located in a low population area, the WCS could not affect nearby residential public receptors, but may affect adjacent commercial or industrial public receptors. The maximum distance to the heat radiation endpoint (5 kilowatts / square meter) for this WCS is 0.1 miles.  This event was selected as being a practical scenario for use in emergency planning and action.

Nebraska Energy LLC has numerous controls in place to prevent such releases and to manage their consequences.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 
 
The

ty of critical process equipment to ensure it is designed and installed correctly and operates properly. Inspections and testing are performed on process equipment, using procedures that follow recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.  Each inspection and test on process equipment is documented, identifying the date, the name of the person who performed the inspection or test, the serial number or other identifier of the equipment, a description of the inspection or test performed, and the results.

The Nebraska Energy LLC PSM mechanical integrity requirements apply to the following equipment in PSM covered process equipment:

? Pressure Vessels and Storage Tanks;
? Piping Systems (including valves, heat exchange, etc.);
? Relief and Vent Systems and Devices;
? Emergency Shutdown Systems;
? Controls (including Monitoring Devices and Sensors, Alarms, and Interlocks.); and
? Pumps and Compressors

Nebraska Energy ensures that equipment deficiencies outside of the acceptable limits are corrected before further use or in a safe and timely manner when necessary means are taken to provide safe operation.  Nebraska Energy will ensure that new or modified plants and equipment are fabricated, and installed properly and consistent with design specifications.  Nebraska Energy will ensure that maintenance materials, spare parts, and equipment are suitable for the application for which they will be used.
.
 
SAFE WORK PRACTICES
 
Nebraska Energy LLC has developed and implemented safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during work activities such as lockout/tagout; confined space entry; opening process equipment or piping; and control over entrance into a facility by maintenance, contractor, laboratory, or other support personnel. These safe work practices apply both to employees and to contractor employees.
 
MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE
 
Nebraska Energy requires that a Management of Change (MOC) be performed for any modification to equipment, pro

cedures, raw materials, and process conditions of a PSM covered process.

The Nebraska Energy LLC Management of Change program ensures that modifications to the process are reviewed before installation to ensure that no unforeseen hazards are introduced.  The modification is also reviewed after installation, but before startup, to ensure that the installation met all safety and design requirements.  The MOC process also requires that equipment records, process safety information, operator training, and operating procedures are updated when changes in the process occur.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
 
Nebraska Energy requires any incidents that resulted in a release of a highly hazardous chemical, or near misses, must be investigated.  The incident investigation will be started as soon as possible, but no later than 48 hours following the incident.  A team consisting of at least one person knowledgeable in the process will investigate the incident. The Process Incident Investigation Teams gather, examine, and report the facts pertaining to each process incident.  Nebraska Energy LLC has established a system to promptly address and resolve the reported incident investigation findings and recommendations.  Nebraska Energy LLC then implements  appropriate preventative measures to reduce the potential for future recurrence of similar process incidents.  All affected Nebraska Energy LLC personnel and contractors review the completed incident investigation reports.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS
 
Nebraska Energy LLC will certify compliance with the provisions of PSM and RMP at least every three (3) years through the completion of compliance audits.  The compliance audits will verify that the procedures and practices developed under the standard are adequate and are being implemented.  Nebraska Energy LLC compliance audits are conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  A report of the findings of the audit and recommendations are developed and documented noting findings

? Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level);
? Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases;
? Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system;
? Atmospheric relief and vent devices;
? Release Mitigation;
? Trained emergency response personnel; and
? Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing)
 
FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
 
Nebraska Energy LLC has an excellent record of accident prevention over the past 5 years.

There has been one accidental release of regulated substances that resulted in onsite effects during the prior five years at Nebraska Energy LLC.  There have been no accidental releases of regulated substances that resulted in offsite effects during the prior five years at Nebraska Energy LLC.

Nebraska Energy LLC investigates every incident thoroughly to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from recurring.

The following summarizes of the number of incidents that have occurred during the past 5 years which had onsite or offsite effects:
Number of RMP events with Onsite Effects
? 2003 ? 0
? 2002 ? 0

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
 
Nebraska Energy LLC maintains a written emergency action plan, which is in place to help 
protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and deconta

mination requirements.  In addition, Nebraska Energy LLC has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  When necessary, the emergency response program is updated based on modifications made to Nebraska Energy LLC processes.  The emergency response program changes are administered through the MOC process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes.
 
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
 
Nebraska Energy LLC resolves all findings and recommendations from PHA?s, some of which result in modifications to the process.
